'''sidux''' [[Ipa|[ziËdÊks]]] is a desktop-oriented [[Linux distribution]] based on [[Debian]] unstable, which uses the codename Sid. The distribution consists of a [[LiveCD]] (bootable CD-ROM) for [[i686]] or [[amd64]] architecture and can be installed to a hard drive through a graphical installer.
+
'''sidux''' [[Ipa|[ziËdÊks]]] is a desktop-oriented [[Linux distribution]] based on [[Debian]] unstable, which uses the codename Sid. The distribution consists of a [[Live CD]] (bootable CD-ROM) for [[i686]] or [[amd64]] architecture and can be installed to a hard drive through a graphical installer.
sidux is maintained by a team of developers including former [[Kanotix]] developer Stefan Lippers-Hollmann (slh). Initial administration was managed by The sidux Foundation, Inc. located in the [[United States]]. Now the Berlin, Germany based [http://sidux-ev.org sidux e.V.] is administering and supporting the project.
sidux is maintained by a team of developers including former [[Kanotix]] developer Stefan Lippers-Hollmann (slh). Initial administration was managed by The sidux Foundation, Inc. located in the [[United States]]. Now the Berlin, Germany based [http://sidux-ev.org sidux e.V.] is administering and supporting the project.
Line 25: Line 25:
===Live CD - DVD - USB===
===Live CD - DVD - USB===
â
Each sidux release comes as a [[LiveCD]] or [[LiveDVD]], booting to a graphical desktop without installation. By copying the files from the live CD to an USB drive a [[Live USB]] system can be created.
+
Each sidux release comes as a [[Live CD]] or [[Live DVD]], booting to a graphical desktop without installation. By copying the files from the live CD to an USB drive a [[Live USB]] system can be created.

<li>The support for sidux is mainly done via [[IRC]]
<li>The support for sidux is mainly done via [[IRC]]

â
A running LiveCD presents a button on the desktop which connects the user with the #sidux channel if an internet connection is available.
+
A running Live CD presents a button on the desktop which connects the user with the #sidux channel if an internet connection is available.
Inside the IRC, volunteers give advice and support 24/7 to any questions.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kdedevelopers.org/node/2691 | title=Information about IRC support}}</ref> <br>Also the developers meet there and are available for direct help.<br>
Inside the IRC, volunteers give advice and support 24/7 to any questions.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kdedevelopers.org/node/2691 | title=Information about IRC support}}</ref> <br>Also the developers meet there and are available for direct help.<br>

Line 204: Line 204:
Due to incompatible opinions, a group of former Kanotix developers, accompanied by many users, divided from the Kanotix-project to continue the former goal of [[Kanotix]] in a new project with a defined declaration<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/index.php?module=pnWikka&tag=siduxDeklaration | title=sidux declaration}}</ref>.
Due to incompatible opinions, a group of former Kanotix developers, accompanied by many users, divided from the Kanotix-project to continue the former goal of [[Kanotix]] in a new project with a defined declaration<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/index.php?module=pnWikka&tag=siduxDeklaration | title=sidux declaration}}</ref>.

The sidux project appeared on 2006-11-24,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/Article2.html | title=initial-sidux-announcement}}</ref> with the goal of providing a hard disk installable Debian Sid-based LiveCD distribution.
+
The sidux project appeared on 2006-11-24,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/Article2.html | title=initial-sidux-announcement}}</ref> with the goal of providing a hard disk installable Debian Sid-based Live CD distribution.
The first sidux preview appeared on the 2007-01-24<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/Article73.html | title=sidux-pre1-announce}}</ref> with the finished release appearing on 2007-02-22,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/Article116.html | title=2007-01-announcement}}</ref> codenamed 2007-01 âÎ§Î¬Î¿Ï"(chaos).

During the [http://www.linuxtag.org/2007/ linuxtag 2007] (an open source fair in Berlin) a special linuxtag-edition was distributed at the shared booth of KDE e.V. and sidux.

Line 219: Line 219:
== Software ==
== Software ==
â
sidux releases contain only [[free software]] as defined by the [[Debian Free Software Guidelines|Debian Free Software Guidelines (DFSG)]]. To aid proof of compliance, a monolithic tarball containing the source for all packages used in the release is provided alongside the LiveCD ISOs.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://debian.tu-bs.de/project/sidux/release/ | title=release-source-repository}}</ref>
+
sidux releases contain only [[free software]] as defined by the [[Debian Free Software Guidelines|Debian Free Software Guidelines (DFSG)]]. To aid proof of compliance, a monolithic tarball containing the source for all packages used in the release is provided alongside the Live CD ISOs.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://debian.tu-bs.de/project/sidux/release/ | title=release-source-repository}}</ref>
Access to non-free software such as codecs, plugins and wlan firmware can be enabled by configuring contrib and non-free Debian and sidux repositories in /etc/apt/sources.list
Access to non-free software such as codecs, plugins and wlan firmware can be enabled by configuring contrib and non-free Debian and sidux repositories in /etc/apt/sources.list
â
In keeping with the evolutionary nature of the "unstable" Debian branch, sidux releases do not provide an upgrade path from previous release versions. Rather, once sidux is installed, incremental updates are performed via regular "dist-upgrades". The idea of a sidux "release" is instead to improve LiveCD hardware support, performance, flexibility and reliability, built from the current debian unstable repository.
+
In keeping with the evolutionary nature of the "unstable" Debian branch, sidux releases do not provide an upgrade path from previous release versions. Rather, once sidux is installed, incremental updates are performed via regular "dist-upgrades". The idea of a sidux "release" is instead to improve Live CD hardware support, performance, flexibility and reliability, built from the current debian unstable repository.
sidux also provides a "meta-package installer"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/index.php?module=pnWikka&tag=zadminMetaPakete | title=meta-packages}}</ref> for installation of related packages for common requirements via a graphical install process. Existing meta-packages include security, graphics, games, educational software and to provide support for older computers.
sidux also provides a "meta-package installer"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sidux.com/index.php?module=pnWikka&tag=zadminMetaPakete | title=meta-packages}}</ref> for installation of related packages for common requirements via a graphical install process. Existing meta-packages include security, graphics, games, educational software and to provide support for older computers.
